Information
Welcome to KissHMVC

KissHMVC (CodeIgniter's illegitimate lovechild) is modeled after the CodeIgniter framework which I personally love. If you're just starting to learn PHP CodeIgniter is a great framework to begin with. It's simple to understand and isn't bloated like many other frameworks. KissHMVC follows the same philosophy! It's a compilation of code from around the web, studying how it worked, ALOT of trial & error, and this is the result. If you trust my code feel free to use it but make sure to keep all licenses and copyrights intact if you plan to use or make derivatives of it. If you decide to use my framework to modify and create your own, please let me know so I can mention you on my website, thanks! You can also look through my code if you're worried about security and make any changes as necessary to secure it yourself because I'm still in the beginning stages of developing the framework. It should be simple enough to understand. I believe code should be simple enough to understand in case you come back to it years later but also for new coders that are still learning themselves.

But anyways, like any framework there could be vulnerabilities and I'm not claiming to be a PHP expert. You've been warned! I'm also not entirely sure how well this framework will hold up to massive applications. It will be interesting to hear back from some of you that have attempted. The great thing about my framework is that it's the best of both worlds. You can use normal MVC which has the added bonus of loading Controllers unlike CodeIgniter which only lets you load Models and Views. Or, you have the option to use Modules ( another feature CI doesn't offer straight out of the box ) to organize your application.

If you're familiar with CodeIgniter then KissHMVC will be easy to learn. I'm not trying to compete with other frameworks although that may be a possibility in the future depending on any contributers that would like to help me make that a reality and also my ability to make progress on it myself. I'd also like to make a side note that there's a framework coming out at the end of 2019 called Trongate by a YouTuber I follow which will also have similar syntax to CodeIgniter and also make use of Modules. So if you like CodeIgniter and Modules then you will also want to check that out and especially since that will be much safer to use than my framework at the moment.

Furthermore, I've also been looking at CodeIgniter's core classes and getting a general idea of how it works and then creating similar code but not as complex because some of it is beyond my head. I started this project several months ago and then recently began working on it again. I rewrote the code and created a better file structure following the design pattern CodeIgniter uses including a tutorial I found that also uses a similar pattern. This framework was meant to teach myself and also help others learning how to assemble a framework from scratch. This project wasn't meant to become a legitimate framework, however, it has slowly started become just that! It's far from complete but it's a great start. I still need to address security concerns, complete library classes, helpers, etc. If you would like to contribute, offer coding tips, or use my code feel free to do so. And keep checking back often for updates as I continue to make progress!

Changelog
Current Version 1.1.0

  • [1.0.0] — 19-02-01

    • Bug Fix

      • Ability to load controllers and modules; partly working so far.

      • Methods with an underscore are now private with the bit of code I just added.

      • Partially working custom routes and config.

      • Rewrote code from an older project and updated file structure to follow the coding pattern CodeIgniter uses.

  • [1.0.0] — 19-03-04

    • Bug Fix

      • You can load controllers from modules and vice versa.

  • [1.0.0] — 19-03-06

    • Fixed

      • Got URL Helpers working (e.g. base_url function); Config array was clashing with the database config array. Created separate files to hold arrays but may revert back if I find a better solution.

  • [1.0.0] — 19-03-09

    • Fixed

      • Custom Routes mostly working now. However, in the process the default controller isn't working and it also affected loading methods. So you also have to set your methods in the routes config file as well until I fix those two problems.

  • [1.0.0] — 19-03-11

    • Fixed

      • Default contoller now working in Custom Routes.

      • Fixed the problem with URI params for the most part, now they're being passed as strings instead of arrays. It had something to do with the way I setup params in the Request class.

  • [1.0.0] — 19-03-16

    • Fixed

      • Got $this->load working in views including modules working sort of as a result because the load property also has access to the module method as well; Still needs work, however, cause this is just a quick fix solution but at least it works for now until I find a way of making the load property globally accessible.

  • [1.0.0] — 19-03-25

    • Fixed (Happy Birthday To Me)

      • Got modules loading view partials in other view files for the most part.

  • [1.0.0] — 19-04-07

    • Fixed

      • Got model data loading in / from modules somewhat but still a work in progress. Also, now when you load a module without specifying a method it will attempt to load the index method by default.

  • [1.0.0] — 19-04-17

    • Fixed

      • Got default_controller loading modules.

  • [1.0.0] — 19-04-21

    • Fixed

      • Combined the Loader class in to one file and so far everything is working fine except that it tries to load file names containing the same name twice (e.g. header, footer, and navbar). Also, removed M_Loader, KISS_Module, and KISS_Module_Model files and now Models extend KISS_Model, Controllers & Modules extend KISS_Controller.

  • [1.0.1] — 19-04-29

    • Fixed

      • Got private methods (indicated by an underscore prefix) working with custom routes; you can even specify a custom error page or if left null it will load the default error controller/class.
